qas.question: Where was Washington University located during the first half of the 1800's.
When did Washington University begin to expand west?
What architecture firm was hired by the Board of Directors at Washington University?
Who was on the committee that found a new site for Washington University?

answers.text: Robert S. Brookings, Henry Ware Eliot, and William Huse

qas.question: What nickname was given to the new campus site?
In what decade was the Manual School established?
Who was one of the university's Board of Directors members in the 1890s?
What city was Robert Brookings originally from?
What is one of the streets that the Danforth campus now lies next to?

context: Washington University spent its first half century in <a0_0>downtown <b7_0>St. Louis<b7_0/><a0_0/> bounded by Washington Ave., <b9_0>Lucas Place<b9_0/>, and Locust Street. By <a1_0>the <b5_0>1890s<b5_0/><a1_0/>, owing to the dramatic expansion of the Manual School and a new benefactor in <b6_0>Robert Brookings<b6_0/>, the University began to move west. The University Board of Directors began a process to find suitable ground and hired the landscape architecture firm <a2_0><b8_0>Olmsted, Olmsted & Eliot of Boston<b8_0/><a2_0/>. A committee of <a3_0>Robert S. Brookings, Henry Ware Eliot, and William Huse<a3_0/> found a site of 103 acres (41.7 ha) just beyond Forest Park, located west of the city limits in St. Louis County. The elevation of the land was thought to resemble the Acropolis and inspired the nickname of <a4_0>"Hilltop" campus<a4_0/>, renamed the Danforth campus in 2006 to honor former chancellor William H. Danforth.
